sen.j: 大久保 忠隣（おおくぼ ただちか）は、戦国時代 (日本)から江戸時代前期にかけての武将・譜代大名。
sen.e: Tadachika OKUBO was a busho (Japanese military commander) and fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) in the Sengoku period to the early Edo period.

Tadachika OKUBO was a busho (Japanese military commander) and fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) to the early Edo period.
sen.cmt: Sengoku periodの補足を追加しました。
sen.e: Tadachika OKUBO was a busho (Japanese military commander) and fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) to the early Edo period.

sen.j: 相模国小田原藩の初代藩主。
sen.e: He was the first lord of Odawara Domain, Sagami Province.
He was the first lord of the Odawara Domain, Sagami Province.
sen.cmt: the Odawara Domainとし、余分なスペース消去しました。
sen.e: He was the first lord of the Odawara Domain, Sagami Province.

sen.j: 講談で有名な旗本の大久保忠教の甥にあたる。
sen.e: He was a nephew of Tadataka OKUBO, a bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), who was famous for kodan storytelling.
He was a nephew of Tadataka OKUBO, a bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), who was famous for kodan storytelling.
He was a nephew of Tadataka OKUBO, a bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), who was famous for kodan storytelling.

sen.j: 小田原藩大久保家初代。
sen.e: He was the first head of the OKUBO clan of Odawara Domain.
He was the first head of the Okubo family of the Odawara Domain.
sen.cmt: the OKUBO clan→the Okubo familyに修正、the Odawara Domainとしました。
sen.e: He was the first head of the Okubo family of the Odawara Domain.

sen.j: 天文22年（1553年）、松平氏（徳川氏）の重臣・大久保忠世の長男として三河国額田郡上和田（愛知県岡崎市）で生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as the first boy of Tadayo OKUBO, a senior vassal of the Matsudaira clan (Tokugawa clan), in Kamiwada, Nukata district, Mikawa Province (present-day Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture) in 1553.
He was born as the first boy of Tadayo OKUBO, a senior vassal of the Matsudaira clan (Tokugawa clan), in Kamiwada, Nukata County, Mikawa Province (present-day Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture) in 1553.
sen.cmt: Nukata district→Nukata Countyに修正しました。
sen.e: He was born as the first boy of Tadayo OKUBO, a senior vassal of the Matsudaira clan (Tokugawa clan), in Kamiwada, Nukata County, Mikawa Province (present-day Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture) in 1553.

sen.j: 永禄6年（1563年）、11歳の時から徳川家康に仕え、三河一向一揆などで戦う。
sen.e: He started to serve Ieyasu TOKUGAWA when he was eleven years old in 1563 and fought in the Mikawa Ikko Ikki (an uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa Province).
He started to serve Ieyasu TOKUGAWA when he was eleven years old in 1563 and fought in the Mikawa Ikko Ikki (an uprising of Ikkoshu sect followers in Mikawa Province).
He started to serve Ieyasu TOKUGAWA when he was eleven years old in 1563 and fought in the Mikawa Ikko Ikki (an uprising of Ikkoshu sect followers in Mikawa Province).

sen.j: 家康の家臣として元亀元年（1570年）の姉川の戦い、元亀3年（1572年）の三方ヶ原の戦い、天正12年（1584年）の小牧・長久手の戦い、天正18年（1590年）の小田原合戦などに参戦し、武功を挙げた。
sen.e: He joined the battle as a vassal of Ieyasu in the Battle of Anegawa (1570), the Battle of Mikatagahara (1572), the Battle of Komaki-Nagakute (1584), or the Odawara Campaign (1590) and showed distinguished military exploits.

He joined the battle as a vassal of Ieyasu in the Battle of Anegawa (1570), the Battle of Mikatagahara (1572), the Battle of Komaki-Nagakute (1584), or the Odawara Campaign (1590) and showed distinguished military exploits.

He joined the battle as a vassal of Ieyasu in the Battle of Anegawa (1570), the Battle of Mikatagahara (1572), the Battle of Komaki-Nagakute (1584), or the Odawara Campaign (1590) and showed distinguished military exploits.

sen.j: 文禄2年（1593年）には家康の3男・徳川秀忠付の家老となる。
sen.e: In 1593, he became Karo (chief retainer) of Hidetada Tokugawa, the third son of Ieyasu.
In 1593, he became Karo (chief retainer) of Hidetada TOKUGAWA, the third son of Ieyasu.
sen.cmt: Hidetada Tokugawa→Hidetada TOKUGAWAに修正しました。
sen.e: In 1593, he became Karo (chief retainer) of Hidetada TOKUGAWA, the third son of Ieyasu.

sen.j: 文禄3年（1594年）、父・忠世が死去したため、家督を継いで相模小田原藩6万5000石の領主（のち初代藩主）となる。
sen.e: In 1594, he took over as head of the family and became the first feudal lord of the Odawara Domain, Sagami Province with 65,000-koku (a unit of volume: rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter) when his father, Tadayo, died.

In 1594, he took over as head of the family and became the first feudal lord of the Odawara Domain, Sagami Province with 65,000 koku (a unit of volume: rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter) when his father, Tadayo, died.

In 1594, he took over as head of the family and became the first feudal lord of the Odawara Domain, Sagami Province with 65,000 koku (a unit of volume: rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter) when his father, Tadayo, died.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）の関ヶ原の戦い時には東軍の主力を率いた秀忠に従い中山道を進むが、途中信州上田城に篭城する西軍の真田昌幸に対して、攻撃を主張して本多正信らと対立する。
sen.e: In the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, he followed Hidetada who led the main Eastern army and took Nakasen-do Road, but on the way, he argued that they should attack Masayuki SANADA who belonged to the Western army and was holding Ueda-jo Castle in Shinshu and came into conflict with Masanobu HONDA and others.

In the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, he followed Hidetada who led the main Eastern army and took Nakasen-do Road, but on the way, he argued that they should attack Masayuki SANADA who belonged to the Western army and was holding Ueda-jo Castle in Shinshu and came into conflict with Masanobu HONDA and others.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去しました。
sen.e: In the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, he followed Hidetada who led the main Eastern army and took Nakasen-do Road, but on the way, he argued that they should attack Masayuki SANADA who belonged to the Western army and was holding Ueda-jo Castle in Shinshu and came into conflict with Masanobu HONDA and others.

sen.j: 慶長6年（1601年）、高崎藩13万石への加増を打診されるが固辞した。
sen.e: In 1601, he got a proposal to change his territory to the Takasaki domain and an increase of his yield to 130,000-koku but he tuned down this offer.
In 1601, he got a proposal to change his territory to the Takasaki Domain and an increase of his yield to 130,000 koku but he tuned down this offer.
sen.cmt: domainの頭文字を大文字に変更、130,000-koku→130,000 kokuとしました。
sen.e: In 1601, he got a proposal to change his territory to the Takasaki Domain and an increase of his yield to 130,000 koku but he tuned down this offer.

sen.j: 慶長15年（1610年）には老中に就任し、第2代将軍・徳川秀忠の政権の有力者となり、大御所となった家康が駿府で影響力を行使する二元政治の中、家康重臣である本多正信・本多正純父子と対立する。
sen.e: He assumed a post of roju (member of shogun's council of elders) in 1610 and became an influential political person under the second shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, and conflicted with a father and son of Masanobu HONDA and Masazumi HONDA who were senior vassals of Ieyasu in the dual political system where Ieyasu, Ogosho (retired shogun), still had an influential power in Sunpu.

He assumed a post of roju (member of shogun's council of elders) in 1610 and became an influential political person under the second shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, and conflicted with a father and son of Masanobu HONDA and Masazumi HONDA who were senior vassals of Ieyasu in the dual political system where Ieyasu, Ogosho (retired shogun), still had an influential power in Sunpu.

He assumed a post of roju (member of shogun's council of elders) in 1610 and became an influential political person under the second shogun, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, and conflicted with a father and son of Masanobu HONDA and Masazumi HONDA who were senior vassals of Ieyasu in the dual political system where Ieyasu, Ogosho (retired shogun), still had an influential power in Sunpu.

sen.j: 慶長17年（1612年）の岡本大八事件、慶長19年（1614年）の大久保長安事件による浪人の馬場八左衛門の讒言により（諸説あり、後述）改易され、近江国に配流され、井伊直孝に預けられる。
sen.e: He was punished by being deprived of his fief due to the false charge by Hachizaemon Baba who became a ronin (masterless samurai) in the Incident of Daihachi OKAMOTO (1612) and the Okubo Nagayasu Incident (1614) (there are various theories on this and described later) and he was exiled to the Omi Province and put under the control of Naotaka II.

He was punished by being deprived of his fief due to the false charge by Hachizaemon BABA who became a ronin (masterless samurai) in the Incident of Daihachi OKAMOTO (1612) and the Incident of Nagayasu OKUBO (1614) (there are various theories on this and described later) and he was exiled to the Omi Province and put under the control of Naotaka II.
sen.cmt: Hachizaemon Baba→Hachizaemon BABAに修正、the Incident of Daihachi OKAMOTOに合わせ、the Incident of Nagayasu OKUBOとしました。
sen.e: He was punished by being deprived of his fief due to the false charge by Hachizaemon BABA who became a ronin (masterless samurai) in the Incident of Daihachi OKAMOTO (1612) and the Incident of Nagayasu OKUBO (1614) (there are various theories on this and described later) and he was exiled to the Omi Province and put under the control of Naotaka II.

sen.j: この時、近江栗太郡中村郷に5000石の知行地を与えられている。
sen.e: At that time, he was given chigyo-chi (territory) of 5,000-koku in Nakamura-go, Kurita gun, Omi Province.
At that time, he was given chigyo-chi (territory) of 5,000-koku in Nakamura-go, Kurita County, Omi Province.
sen.cmt: Kurita gun→Kurita Countyに修正、スペース修正しました。
sen.e: At that time, he was given chigyo-chi (territory) of 5,000-koku in Nakamura-go, Kurita County, Omi Province.

sen.j: その後、出家して渓庵道白と号し、寛永5年（1628年）6月27日に死去。
sen.e: After that he entered into priesthood and called himself Keian Dohaku and died in June, 1628.
After that he entered into priesthood and called himself Keian Dohaku and died on July 28, 1628.
sen.cmt: 日付の一部が訳漏れのため訳出しました。(新暦に修正)
sen.e: After that he entered into priesthood and called himself Keian Dohaku and died on July 28, 1628.

sen.j: 享年75。
sen.e: He died at 75.
He died at the age of 75.
sen.cmt: at the age of 75としました。
sen.e: He died at the age of 75.

sen.j: 忠隣の累代における武功が大きかったことから、大久保家の家督は嫡孫の大久保忠職が継ぐことが許され、後に小田原藩主として復帰を果たした。
sen.e: As his successive generations demonstrated great military exploits, Tadamoto OKUBO, his legitimate grandchild, was permitted to take over as the head of the Okubo family and he made a comeback as the lord of the Odawara domain later.

As his successive generations demonstrated great military exploits, Tadamoto OKUBO, his legitimate grandchild, was permitted to take over as head of the Okubo family and he made a comeback as the lord of the Odawara Domain later.
sen.cmt: as the head→as head、domainの頭文字を大文字に変更しました。
sen.e: As his successive generations demonstrated great military exploits, Tadamoto OKUBO, his legitimate grandchild, was permitted to take over as head of the Okubo family and he made a comeback as the lord of the Odawara Domain later.

tit.cmt: 「人物」→統一リストの表記に変更、頭文字を大文字に変更しました。

sen.j: 徳川四天王に劣らぬ武功派で、台徳院殿御実紀には「数年の忠功青史に赫々たり」とある。
sen.e: He belonged to a military exploit group and compared favorably with Tokugawa-shitenno (four generals serving Tokugawa Ieyasu) and was recorded as "showed outstanding loyalty for long years " in "Taitokuindono-jikki", a record book of Hidetada TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 数年の忠功青史に赫々たり の訳、仮訳です。
sen.e: He belonged to a military exploit group and compared favorably with Tokugawa-shitenno (four generals serving Ieyasu TOKUGAWA) and was recorded as "showed outstanding loyalty for long years" in the Taitokuin-dono Gojikki, a record book of Hidetada TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: Tokugawa Ieyasu→Ieyasu TOKUGAWAに修正、Taitokuindono-jikki→the Taitokuin-dono Gojikkiに修正、原文表記に合わせクォーテーション削除、余分なスペース消去しました。
sen.e: He belonged to a military exploit group and compared favorably with Tokugawa-shitenno (four generals serving Ieyasu TOKUGAWA) and was recorded as "showed outstanding loyalty for long years" in the Taitokuin-dono Gojikki, a record book of Hidetada TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 井伊直孝が、家康の死後に大久保忠隣の冤罪を将軍秀忠に嘆願しようと図ったところ、忠隣は家康に対する不忠になるとして、これを断ったとされる。
sen.e: When Naotaka II attempted to supplicate the false charge against Tadachika OKUBO after Ieyasu died, Tadachika was said to turn down this because it was a disloyalty for Ieyasu.

It is said that, when Naotaka II attempted to supplicate Shogun Hidetada for the false charge against Tadachika OKUBO after Ieyasu had died, Tadachika turned down this because it was a disloyalty for Ieyasu.
sen.cmt: 文頭にIt is said that追加、after Ieyasu died→after Ieyasu had died、Tadachika was said to turn down→Tadachika turned downとし、「将軍秀忠に」→訳漏れのため訳出しました。
sen.e: It is said that, when Naotaka II attempted to appeal to Shogun Hidetada regarding the false charge against Tadachika OKUBO after Ieyasu had died, Tadachika rejected the appeal because it would be disloyal to Ieyasu.

sen.j: 関ヶ原の戦いの後に、家康が重臣を集めて後継者に関する相談をしたときに、秀忠の兄の結城秀康や松平忠吉の名前が挙がるなか、忠隣が秀忠を推薦したエピソードも知られる（『台徳院殿御実記』）。
sen.e: There is an episode known that when Ieyasu gathered his vassales and consulted on his successor after the Battle of Sekigahara, Tadachika recommended Hidetada while other candidate names such as Hideyasu YUKI, Hidetada's elder brother, or Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA were mentioned.

There is an episode known that when Ieyasu gathered his vassales and consulted on his successor after the Battle of Sekigahara, Tadachika recommended Hidetada while other candidate names such as Hideyasu YUKI, Hidetada's older brother, or Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA were mentioned ("Taitokuin-dono Gojikki").
sen.cmt: （『台徳院殿御実記』）→訳漏れのため訳出、統一リストに基づき、elder brother→older brotherに修正しました。
sen.e: There is an episode known that when Ieyasu gathered his vassales and consulted on his successor after the Battle of Sekigahara, Tadachika recommended Hidetada while other candidate names such as Hideyasu YUKI, Hidetada's older brother, or Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA were mentioned ("Taitokuin-dono Gojikki").

sen.j: 改易の理由は表向きには忠隣の養女と山口重信との無断婚姻が理由とされているが、実際の理由は大久保長安事件によるとする説や本多正信・正純による策謀とする説、豊臣政権を一掃しようと考えていた家康が、西国大名と親しく、また和平論を唱える可能性のあった忠隣を遠ざけたとする説（三津木國輝『小田原藩主 大久保忠世・忠隣』）など諸説あり、明確な理由は不明である。
sen.e: The reason for his Kaieki, punishmnet, was technically said as the unauthorized marriage of the adopted daughter of Tadachika and Shigenobu YAMAGUCHI, however, there are many thories on the real reasons such as the one by the Okubo Nagayasu Incident, or by the conspiracy of Masanobu HONDA and Masazumi HONDA, or by Ieyasu who had the intention to get rid of the Toyotomi government alienated Tadahide who had a close relationship with Saigoku Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in western Japan) and might present a peace plan (according to "Tadayo and Tadachika OKUBO, the lord of Odawara domain" written by Kuniteru MITSUGI) but the clear reason has not been known.

The reason for his Kaieki, punishment, was technically said as the unauthorized marriage of the adopted daughter of Tadachika and Shigenobu YAMAGUCHI, however, there are many theories on the real reasons such as the one by the Incident of Nagayasu OKUBO, or by the conspiracy of Masanobu HONDA and Masazumi HONDA, or by Ieyasu who had the intention to get rid of the Toyotomi government alienated Tadachika who had a close relationship with Saigoku Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in western Japan) and might present a peace plan (according to the "Tadayo and Tadachika OKUBO, the Lord of the Odawara Domain" written by Kuniteru MITSUGI) but the clear reason has not been known.
sen.cmt: punishment、theoriesのスペルミス修正、the Incident of Nagayasu OKUBOとし、Tadahide→Tadachikaに修正、the "Tadayo and Tadachika OKUBO, the Lord of the Odawara Domain"としました。
sen.e: The reason for his Kaieki, punishment, was technically said as the unauthorized marriage of the adopted daughter of Tadachika and Shigenobu YAMAGUCHI, however, there are many theories on the real reasons such as the one by the Incident of Nagayasu OKUBO, or by the conspiracy of Masanobu HONDA and Masazumi HONDA, or by Ieyasu who had the intention to get rid of the Toyotomi government alienated Tadachika who had a close relationship with Saigoku Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in western Japan) and might present a peace plan (according to the "Tadayo and Tadachika OKUBO, the Lord of the Odawara Domain" written by Kuniteru MITSUGI) but the clear reason has not been known.
